reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s “value is multiplicative across many factors” model used to motivate eutopian fragility (Section 2.4). If that multiplicative/independence framing were badly mistaken, it would weaken one important intuitive support for “no easy eutopia,” but the overall position also leans on many other considerations (historical moral catastrophe examples; moral-view ‘fussiness’ analysis in Section 3) that don’t depend on strict multiplicativity, so centrality is moderate. Strength is low because the essay explicitly presents multiplicativity as a toy model/one way to capture fragility (“one model…”, “relatively independent factors”), and the critique doesn’t argue that additive or interacting models would actually make mostly-great futures common—it merely notes they exist. Still, it’s broadly correct that alternative aggregation/interaction structures could change the quantitative rarity conclusions, so correctness is fairly high. The point is clear, focused, and contains no filler.
title: Additive or non-independent value models could reduce eutopian fragility
